natural problem: How many positive integers less than 60 have an even number of positive divisors?
natural solution: Perfect squares have an odd number of positive divisors, while all other integers have an even number of positive divisors. The perfect squares less than or equal to 60 are 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, and 49.
Therefore, of the 59 positive integers less than 60, 7 of them have an odd number of factors, so $59-7=\boxed{52}$ of them have an even number of factors.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. divisors n = {d. d dvd n \<and> d > 0}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n < 60 \<longrightarrow> even (card (divisors n))"
shows  "card {n. n < 60 \<and> even (card (divisors n))} = 52"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive integers less than 60 have an even number of positive divisors? The final Answer is 52
 ### Proof
 Perfect squares have an odd number of positive divisors, while all other integers have an even number of positive divisors. The perfect squares less than or equal to 60 are 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, and 49.
 Therefore, of the 59 positive integers less than 60, 7 of them have an odd number of factors, so $59-7=\boxed{52}$ of them have an even number of factors.
 *)

theorem
fixes n :: nat and divisors :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. divisors n = {d. d dvd n \<and> d > 0}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n < 60 \<longrightarrow> even (card (divisors n))"
shows  "card {n. n < 60 \<and> even (card (divisors n))} = 52"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For all natural numbers less than 60, if the number of their positive divisors is even, find how many such numbers exist. The final answer is 52.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = {d. d > 0 \<and> n mod d = 0}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<and> n < 60 \<longrightarrow> even (card (f n))"
shows  "card {n. n > 0 \<and> n < 60 \<and> even (card (f n))} = 52"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 How many positive integers less than 60 have an even number of positive divisors? The final Answer is 52
 ### Proof
 Perfect squares have an odd number of positive divisors, while all other integers have an even number of positive divisors. The perfect squares less than or equal to 60 are 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, and 49.
 Therefore, of the 59 positive integers less than 60, 7 of them have an odd number of factors, so $59-7=\boxed{52}$ of them have an even number of factors.
 *)

fixes n :: int and f :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. f n = {d. d > 0 \<and> n mod d = 0}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n > 0 \<and> n < 60 \<longrightarrow> even (card (f n))"
shows  "card {n. n > 0 \<and> n < 60 \<and> even (card (f n))} = 52"

Now consider the set of all positive integers less than 60, and for each of these numbers, count the number of elements in $f(n)$. If this count is even, include that number in a new set. How many elements are in this new set? The final answer is 52.

a_2.formal problem:

fixes n :: int
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. (n > 0 \<and> n < 60 \<and> (card {d. d divides n \<and> d > 0} mod 2 = 0)) \<longrightarrow> P n"
shows  "card {n. P n} = 52"

 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes n :: int and d :: "int \<Rightarrow> int set"
assumes h0 : "\<forall> n. d n = {m. m > 0 \<and> m dvd n}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n. n < 60 \<longrightarrow> (n > 0 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists> m. m \<in> d n \<and> even m))"
shows  "card {n. n < 60 \<and> n > 0 \<and> (\<exists> m. m \<in> d n \<and> even m)} = 52"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem

 *)

shows  "card {n. n < 60 \<and> n > 0 \<and> (\<exists> m. m \<in> d n \<and> even m)} = 52"

 How many positive integers less than 60 have an even number of positive divisors? The final Answer is 52
 ### Proof
 Perfect squares have an odd number of positive divisors, while all other integers have an even number of positive divisors. The perfect squares less than or equal to 60 are 1, 4, 9, 16, 25, 36, and 49.
